title: Microsoft Office Zero-Day: Emergency Patch for Actively Exploited OLE/COM Bypass (CISA KEV)

timeline.event: Microsoft releases emergency out-of-band patch for CVE-2026-21509
CISA adds CVE-2026-21509 to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
Microsoft confirms active exploitation in targeted attacks, discovered by MSTIC
NHS England Digital issues cyber alert for UK healthcare organizations
Microsoft releases additional patches for Office 2016 and 2019 (KB5002713)

simple_summary.what_happened: Microsoft released an emergency out-of-band security update to fix a zero-day vulnerability (CVE-2026-21509) that is being actively exploited in the wild. The flaw allows attackers to bypass OLE security mitigations in Microsoft Office, exposing users to vulnerable COM/OLE controls including Shell.Explorer.1 (embedded Internet Explorer). Microsoft's Threat Intelligence Center discovered the exploitation, suggesting sophisticated threat actors are targeting specific organizations.
simple_summary.who_is_affected: Organizations using any version of Microsoft Office are at risk, including Office 2016, Office 2019, Office LTSC 2021, Office LTSC 2024, and Microsoft 365 Apps for Enterprise. This affects virtually every enterprise worldwide that uses Microsoft Office for document processing, making it one of the most widespread potential attack surfaces.
simple_summary.what_attackers_do: Step 1: Craft a malicious Office document containing embedded OLE/COM objects. Step 2: Bypass Microsoft's security mitigations using Shell.Explorer.1 (CLSID {EAB22AC3-30C1-11CF-A7EB-0000C05BAE0B}). Step 3: Deliver the document via phishing email or other social engineering. Step 4: Convince the user to open the malicious document. Step 5: Execute arbitrary code through the embedded browser component which can load local files, execute scripts, and connect to remote servers. Step 6: Establish persistence and potentially move laterally within the organization.
what_you_should_do: Apply Microsoft's emergency patch immediately - Office 2021+ users restart Office applications
Deploy KB5002713 for Office 2016 and 2019 MSI-based installations
Block or monitor for Shell.Explorer.1 COM object usage in Office documents
Enhance email filtering to detect malicious Office attachments
Train users not to open unexpected Office documents from unknown sources
Enable Protected View and configure Office to block macros and embedded objects
Monitor for suspicious Office process behavior and child process spawning
simple_summary.why_this_is_serious: Microsoft Office is deployed on virtually every enterprise endpoint worldwide. The exploitation was discovered by MSTIC, indicating sophisticated threat actors are actively using this in targeted attacks. OLE/COM vulnerabilities have historically been favored by nation-state actors and advanced persistent threat groups for initial access. With the embedded Internet Explorer component able to execute scripts and connect to remote servers, successful exploitation provides a powerful foothold for further attacks. CISA has mandated federal agencies patch by February 16, 2026.

tactics.description: Delivering malicious Office documents via targeted email campaigns
Abusing COM/OLE objects to execute code through Office applications
Using Shell.Explorer.1 to proxy execution through embedded Internet Explorer

tactics.technique_name: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools
tactics.description: Bypassing Microsoft Office security mitigations for OLE objects
Using embedded browser to establish connections to attacker infrastructure

detection_guidance.summary: Monitor for suspicious Office document activity, particularly OLE/COM object instantiation and unexpected child processes spawned by Office applications. Focus on detecting Shell.Explorer.1 usage and network connections from Office processes.

log_sources.description: Process creation events (4688) showing Office spawning unusual child processes
Event ID 1 (Process Create), Event ID 3 (Network Connection), Event ID 7 (Image Load)
Alerts for suspicious Office behavior and exploit attempts
Quarantined or flagged Office document attachments

what_to_look_for.description: Office processes loading or instantiating Shell.Explorer.1 COM object

what_to_look_for.indicator: Office spawning iexplore.exe or browser processes
what_to_look_for.description: WINWORD.EXE, EXCEL.EXE, or POWERPNT.EXE creating Internet Explorer processes
what_to_look_for.log_field: ParentImage contains Office application, Image contains iexplore

what_to_look_for.description: Office applications making unexpected outbound network connections
what_to_look_for.log_field: Sysmon Event ID 3 with Office process as source

what_to_look_for.description: Documents containing embedded OLE objects being opened
what_to_look_for.log_field: Office application loading oleaut32.dll or ole32.dll

immediate_actions.description: Apply Microsoft's out-of-band update for all Office versions immediately
Office 2021+ users must restart applications for server-side fix to take effect
Install security update for Office 2016/2019 MSI installations
Block or quarantine Office documents with embedded OLE objects
Implement Sysmon and SIEM rules to detect Shell.Explorer.1 abuse
Alert users to increased phishing risk with malicious Office documents
